awd_titl_txt: Standard Grant: Internet Infrastructure and Connectivity in Rural Regions of the USA
awd_abstract_narration:
This project will expand understanding of digital inequality by focusing on connectivity challenges in rural communities. In terms of the broader impacts of this project, the findings will speak directly to ongoing struggles and concerns over Internet access. Factors to be studied include telecom industry regulations, policies of the FCC and other agencies, grant and loan programs, and technological innovations emerging out of Academia and the private sector. This project will provide a better understanding of how well governments incentivizing incumbents and rural self-organizing are or are not working and  why. The findings will help inform citizen advocacy groups and communities that are organizing to address their connectivity needs. Furthermore, students will be involved in an outreach activity learning about Native American communities in the area to develop approaches to managing and sharing cultural information informed by the idea of data sovereignty. This research will be of interest to communities, policy makers, technology industries and scholars.

The study will center on two sites: Mendocino county, California and Crook county, Oregon. These sites are selected for their distinctive and contrasting populations and histories. This study will (a) pursue a cultural analysis of the selected sites that is attuned to rural cultural identities in order to examine how practices of Internet use are being defined and (b)  look at the material affordances and constraints on access through a focus on infrastructure with special attention paid to the collective efforts by communities to cooperatively self-provision connectivity. This proposal will draw from new materialist theories because it places culture as well as collectivities and places back into the conversation on the digital divide. This research will broaden the conversation around access and connectivity to include culture, place and social institutions as well as individual user behavior.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Social and Economic Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: SOC STUDIES OF SCI, ENG & TECH

por.por_cntn:
This research is about the impact of the Internet in rural communities of the American West. The project studied the Internet from a couple of perspectives. (1) the perspective of those who use and rely on the Internet in rural areas particularly in terms of its relevance to traditional rural livelihoods (2) the perspective of workers and business owners who build and maintain the infrastructure of the Internet (i.e. fiber optic cables, data centers, wireless Internet service providers, etc). This included better understanding the desirability and value of tech jobs in rural areas of California and Oregon.

I found that rural communities turn to tech to overcome declining rural economies and dwindling populations. While occasionally big tech firms, like Facebook, wish to locate facilities in their area, but rural communities have little leverage in making deals. Leaders and workers often relate on-site tech jobs to blue-collar ideals, seeing appeal when the work is embodied 'labor,' skilled, and provides a family-wage. Rural workers also use tech to work remotely, not only to do white-collar telework, but to address or attempt to overcome challenges in traditional industries like cattle ranching, fishing, and logging. Additionally tech is employed by Native American communities in various ways as part of efforts toward cultural revitalization. Many rural areas have poor Internet and are left out of service areas for major Internet Service Providers due to expense and lack of a regulatory mandate to serve such communities. Innovative forms of connectivity, especially small mom-and-pop wireless ISPs fill the gaps, but such businesses are run with varying degrees of competence.

The concrete outcomes of this work, so far, includes two published, peer-reviewed journal articles and a report, with two further journal articles not yet submitted for review. The findings have been disseminated to rural communities as well as other researchers. A number of PhD and Masters students had the opportunity to be involved in this research and learned research skills and some also participated in outreach activities with members of the Native American community. Other outcomes include outreach activities developed in partnership with members of the Manchester Band of Pomo Indians and other members of the Native American community in the Mendocino area of California. A cultural archive with educational materials was built for this community as well to repatriate digital cultural materials kept in UC-Berkeley archives.


Last Modified: 01/07/2022
Modified by: Jenna Burrell
